Available online 5 March 2022 Account Rational design and precise manipulation of nano-catalysts Qinggang Liu Junguo Ma Chen Chen * Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China Department of Chemistry Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 China Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China * Corresponding author Nano-catalysis plays a vital role in the chemical transformations and significantly impacts the booming modern chemical industry. The rapid technological enhancements have resulted in serious energy and environmental issues, which are currently spurring the exploration of the novel nano-catalysts in diverse fields. In order to develop the efficient nano-catalysts, it is essential to understand their fundamental physicochemical properties, including the coordination structures of the active centers and substrate-adsorbate interactions. Subsequently, the nano-catalyst design with precise manipulation at the atomic level can be attained. In this account, we have summarized our extensive investigation of the factors impacting nano-catalysis, along with the synthetic strategies developed to prepare the nano-catalysts for applications in electrocatalysis, photocatalysis and thermocatalysis. Finally, a brief conclusion and future research directions on nano-catalysis have also been presented. Graphical Abstract Focusing on the recent progress in Chen's group, this review summarizes the combined synthetic chemistry, theoretical modeling, and spectroscopy studies of nano-catalysts together with their applications in electrocatalysis, photocatalysis and thermocatalysis. Keywords Nano-catalysis Single-atom catalysts Water splitting Oxygen reduction reaction CO2 reduction reaction Silane oxidation Benzene oxidation N-formylation 1 Introduction Nano-catalysis provides many opportunities for chemical transformations, ranging from chemical manufacturing to energy conversion and storage [ 1–5 ]. By far, mainly due to the recovery aspect, the heterogeneous catalysis has received a significant research attention, with its application covering approximately 80% of all catalytic processes [ 6–10 ]. However, the significant diversity of the active sites on the heterogeneous catalysts brings inherent difficulties in the design and fine-tuning of the active centers, thus, causing poor activity and product selectivity. Thus, the heterogeneous catalysis is faced with a major challenge to meet the needs for the sustainable development of society [ 11–13 ]. The research on catalysis over the past decades has made it clear that an ideal catalyst should effectively govern the key elementary steps, such as the adsorption of the reactants, diffusion of the intermediates and desorption of the products [ 14,15 ]. As these elementary steps involve electron interactions between the active site and adsorbate, thus, the adjustment of the electron distribution of the active center can be used to tune its catalytic performance, such as the activation energy barrier that determines the reactivity and the choice of reaction pathway [ 14 ]. With the development of the computational chemistry, the key role of the electronic properties during the surface catalytic reactions can be theoretically unveiled. For instance, the frontier molecular orbital theory suggests that the bonding of reactants on the active centers is highly dependent on the interaction between the frontier orbits (HOMO and LUMO) of the reactants with those of the active centers [ 16–20 ]. The d-band center theory provides a further understanding on the role of the electronic states, which emphasizes that the density of the d-band electrons near the Fermi level can significantly affect the catalytic behavior [ 21–25 ]. So far, to tailor the catalytic behavior of a nano-catalyst, a great deal of research work has been done to reveal the potential impact of various factors (size, shape, support, etc.) [ 26–31 ] as well as to observe the kinetics of the catalysis process with the aid of the advanced spectroscopic techniques at the molecular/atomic level [ 32–38 ]. Further, owing to the significant advancements in the synthetic chemistry, it is feasible to achieve the fabrication of the architecture-controlled nano-catalysts, thus, remarkably boosting their catalytic performance. For instance, the noble-metal-based catalysts, featuring coke-resistance, CO-tolerance and high atom economy, can be facilely obtained by mixing the additives with the primary components [ 39–44 ]. However, the development of the new strategies for synthesizing the pertinent well-defined active centers for catalysis continues to be considered important, as a majority of the “synthesized” nano-catalysts actually follow the empirical recipes. One of the key barriers hampering nano-catalysis is the lack of an atomic level understanding of the operation of the catalytic materials. For instance, the doping of a hetero-element induces the lattice strain and alters the electronic states of a catalyst. More importantly, it introduces new active centers with the formation of the dual active sites [ 45–50 ]. These functional properties render the material suitable for a wide range of applications, however, the increased complexity presents significant challenges to decipher the influence of the various factors on the catalyst reactivity to design the desired active centers. Recently, modern catalysis have entered the golden era owing to the development of the single-atom catalysts [ 51–56 ]. With the characteristics of 100% dispersion and uniform active center, the single-atom catalysts (SACs) offer advanced opportunities for exploring the catalytic performances of metals [ 57–60 ]. More importantly, the studies of the interatomic interactions between the surrounding environment and active atoms would shed light on the catalytic process over the multi-atom sites in nano-catalysts. In this account, we have summarized our extensive investigation of the atomically precise catalysis, along with the synthetic strategies developed to prepare the nano-catalysts for applications in electrocatalysis, photocatalysis and thermocatalysis (Fig. 1 ). 2 Electrocatalysis In recent years, the increasing consumption of the non-renewable energy has resulted in a severe energy crisis. In addition, substantial CO2 emissions have caused global climate worsening, such as the greenhouse effect [ 61–63 ]. The identification of the alternative renewable energy sources and efficient techniques to convert CO2 into energy-rich chemical compounds represents an optimal approach to address these threats. The electrocatalytic water splitting and CO2 reduction, driven by low cost and renewable electricity, represent the promising approaches for the sustainable energy development in the future [ 64,65 ]. In these clean energy generation, storage and conversion technologies, four types of redox reactions, namely oxygen evolution reaction (OER), hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR), are involved. In the following sections, our recent findings with respect to the design of the promising electrocatalysts for water splitting, ORR and CO2RR have been discussed. 2.1 Water splitting As a green energy carrier, H2 has become a promising alternative to the current fossil fuel-based energy systems [ 66 ]. The electrocatalytic water splitting reaction involving OER and HER provides a promising way to convert low-density renewable power and H2O into high-purity H2 [ 67 ]. However, the sluggish kinetics of OER typically lead to a high overpotential, with poor electrochemical performance of the electrocatalysts. In order to accelerate the reaction kinetics and to attain a low overpotential, the noble metal catalysts, such as platinum, IrO2 and RuO2, are predominantly employed in the state-of-the-art electrocatalysts [ 68–70 ]. However, the astronomical cost and dwindling supply of the noble metals severely limit the large-scale applications. Over the past few decades, extensive research work has been done to develope cost-effective water splitting electrocatalysts. The transition metal-based catalysts (Fe, Ni, Mn, Co, etc.) are considered to be among the best alternatives to the noble metal electrocatalysts for water splitting [ 71,72 ]. However, the design of the high-efficiency bifunctional catalysts based on the transition metal-based materials is still a challenging task. Recently, our group has designed a novel hybrid CoP catalyst embedding in the N-doped carbon nanotube hollow polyhedron (NCNHP) derived from ZIF-8@ZIF-67 via the pyrolysis-oxidation-phosphorylation method (Fig. 2(a) ) [ 73 ]. The electrochemical measurements showed that the CoP/NCNHP catalyst acted as a bifunctional catalyst for both HER and OER with a significant electrocatalytic performance. When the overall water splitting is performed with the CoP/NCNHP catalyst, a current density of 10 mA·cm−2 can be obtained at 1.64 V (Fig. 2(b)). Further, the performance remained robust even after 36 h of continuous operation (Fig. 2(c)). Combining the theoretical and spectroscopy techniques, the superior catalytic activity of the CoP/NCNHP catalyst could be related to the following factors: (1) The results of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and X-ray near-edge structure (XANES) revealed that, in the CoP/NCNHP catalyst, the Co and P species had partial positive and negative charges, which could act as proton acceptors and hydride acceptors, respectively, thus, leading to the enhanced HER activity. In the reaction process, the surface Co atoms would be partially oxidized, and the formed CoP/CoOOH species acted as the real active sites for the OER process. Because of the conductive properties, CoP provides an effective electronic channel for the CoOOH, thus, accelerating the OER process. (2) The porous N-doped nanotubes endowed the CoP/NCNHP with abundantly available active sites, and more importantly, accelerated the charge/mass transfer for the electrocatalytic process. (3) The CoP NPs were firmly embedded in the NCNHP support, which inhibited their aggregation and improved their stability. (4) The results from DFT calculations further confirmed the transfer of electron from NCNHP to CoP, which increased the d electron density near the Fermi level, thereby enhancing the H bond strength and improving the electrocatalytic activity (Figs. 2(d)–(f)). Overall, the CoP/NCNHP worked as an efficient, stable dual-functional electrocatalyst due to the synergy between CoP NPs and N-doped hollow carbon nanotubes. Based on these findings, a MoP electrocatalyst featuring a hierarchical architecture was also designed by encapsulating the MoP NPs in the hollow spherical NC thin layers (denoted as MoP@NCHSs) [ 74 ]. In order to synthesize the NC skeleton with a hollow spherical structure, the polystyrene spheres were used as the sacrificial template. H3PMo12O40·nH2O was employed as an initiator to trigger the polymerization of the pyrrole monomers. It was noted that the catalyst that was pyrolyzed at 900 °C (MoP@NCHSs-900) exhibited excellent stability and activity with the 10 mA cm−2 current density being achieved at 92 mV (Figs. 3(a) and (b) ). By employing the characterization techniques such as XPS, XANES and transmission electron microscopy (TEM), a quantitative analysis of the MoP@NCHSs catalysts with different ratios and configurations of the N atoms was conducted. It was revealed that the ratio of the pyridine N atoms was positively correlated with the HER performance. To reveal the actual active sites, a series of poison tests were conducted by using SCN− as the poisoning reagent for the Mo centres and H3PO4 as the blocking agent for the pyridinic N. It was observed that the HER performance of MoP@NCHSs-900 was significantly suppressed, thus, suggesting that both Mo and N species significantly contributed towards the catalytic performance. In order to further explore the role of the MoP NPs, the acid etching (16 mol/L HNO3) test was conducted to remove the MoP species. The activity of the resultant sample was observed to be drastically reduced. The theoretical calculations were conducted to reveal the synergistic effect between the MoP NPs and the NC shell with different N species. It was observed that only the pyridinic N could cooperate with the MoP species to accelerate the HER process. The strong interaction enhanced the electron density on the pyridinic N sites, thus, favoring the splitting of the H2O molecules (Figs. 3(c) and (d)). Compared with the original MoP, this interaction also lowered the d-band center of Mo atoms, thus weakening the Mo–H bond and promoting the desorption of H2. Moreover, the pyridinic N atoms at the interface possessed an ability to repel the adsorption of the OH* species. Together these factors have enabled the MoP/pyridinic-N ensemble to catalyze the HER process with a high activity. In addition to the transition metal Co- and Mo-based catalysts, other transition metal compounds such as Fe-based phosphides have also been proven to be bifunctionally active toward the HER and OER. For example, Wang et al. [ 75 ] reported the preparation of 3D FeP nanotubes covered with iron oxide/phosphate species towards water splitting. The material exhibited remarkable activity and stability in alkaline media, with the current up to 10 mA cm−2 at a voltage of 1.69 V. Despite these advances in bifunctional water splitting electrocatalysis, there are still many challenges (for example, developing of acid-stable catalysts with high stability) that must be addressed for practical uses. Hence, there is still more work to be done along this direction. 2.2 ORR Developing the efficient electrocatalysts for ORR is crucial for the new generation energy storage equipment, such as fuel cells and metal-air cells [ 76 ]. However, in the proton-exchange membrane fuel cells, the ORR process is inherently 6 orders of magnitude slower than the hydrogen oxidation process, severely limiting the practical application of the fuel cell-driven vehicles [ 77,78 ]. Similarly, the metal-air battery is also strongly dependent on the performance of the ORR electrocatalysts [ 79 ]. In order to maximize the battery efficiency, both cathode and anode typically consist of the Pt-based catalysts, along with a carbon black based support. Therefore, it would be advantageous to reduce the Pt loadings, or even replace them with the earth-abundant and cost-effective base metals. For the supported catalysts, a little attention has been paid to the fact that a fraction of the catalytic particles are embedded in the support material. It results in a partial failure of the catalytic surface, and the ratio of the failure surface increases on decreasing the particle size. As an alternative, a high atomic utilization can be readily achieved by constructing the open three-dimensional (3D) nanostructures. The hollow structure reduces the number of the ineffective noble metal atoms buried in the interior, with their unusual geometry providing a pathway to tailor the physical and chemical properties. Based on this, a novel class of bimetallic nanoframe electrocatalysts have been developed exploiting the structural evolution of the bimetallic NPs [ 80 ]. Specifically, the PtNi3 polyhedrons transform into the 3D hollow Pt3Ni nanoframes in the nonpolar solvents (such as chloroform and hexane), which impart the surface with the 3D molecular accessibility (Fig. 4(a) ). Interestingly, a Pt-skin surface structure could be readily achieved by subjecting the as-prepared Pt3Ni nanoframes to a controlled heat treatment. For the hollow Pt3Ni nanoframes, the high angle annular dark field-scanning transmission electron microscope (HAADF-STEM) images revealed a single crystalline rhombic dodecahedron architecture consisting of 24 edges (~2 nm in width). The energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) line analysis (Fig. 4(b)) confirmed the existence of the Pt-skin on the surface of the nanoframes with a thickness of approx. 2 Pt atoms. The surface strain endowed the Pt3Ni nanoframes with the novel functional properties. As a result, at 0.95 V, the catalytic activity of the Pt3Ni nanoframes was 16 times higher than that of the commercial Pt/C electrocatalyst (Fig. 4(c)). The influence of the Pt-skin-induced surface strain on the catalytic process was studied using the density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The Pt-skin of the Pt3Ni nanoframes coupled with the highly electrochemically active surface area provides a new pathway to link the well-defined active surface. Compared with the commercial Pt/C catalyst, the synergy between the active Pt3Ni nanoframes and open structure enables the reactants to access both the external and internal active sites, resulting in a much higher mass activity. More importantly, at 0.9 V, the mass activity of the Pt3Ni nanoframes (5.7 A mg−1 Pt) is one order of magnitude higher than the 2017 target of the US Department of Energy (0.44 A mg−1 Pt). In addition to the remarkable catalytic activity, the Pt3Ni nanoframes exhibit a significant stability throughout the electrochemical operation. The results show that the Pt3Ni nanostructures can be cycled between 0.6 and 1.0 V at different scanning rates from 2 to 200 mV s−1 for 10000 times without a significant decline in performance (Fig. 4(d)). For the Pt/C electrocatalysts, owing to the agglomeration of the Pt particles and dissolution of the surface Pt atoms through the oxidation/reduction process, such cycles can lead to a significant decline in the specific surface area (~ 40%). These results further clarify the origin of the high-performance of the Pt3Ni nanoframes. The open nanoframes solve some of challenges for the design of advanced nano-catalysts, such as high surface-to-volume ratio and 3D surface molecular accessibility. The proposed method of structural evolution from the solid polyhedra to the hollow nanoframes can be easily applied to prepare other polymetallic catalysts, including PtCu, PtCo, Pt/Pd-Ni and Pt/Rh-Ni. 2.3 CO2RR The electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 provides an efficient pathway to reduce the global carbon emission and store the low-density renewable electricity. However, it is still quite challenging owing to the weak catalytic activity and poor selectivity [ 81 ]. As the C=O bond in the CO2 molecule is extremely stable, a high overpotential is needed to overcome the activation barrier, which leads to a low CO2 conversion efficiency of the electrocatalysts. In order to promote the development of the practical electrocatalytic CO2 reduction technology, it is vital to develop the high-efficiency CO2RR catalysts with low cost. To achieve this, a robust CO2RR electrocatalyst was developed via an N-coordination strategy, in which the atomically dispersed Co-N5 site anchored on the hollow N-doped polymer-derived porous carbon spheres [ 82 ]. The synthesis procedure is presented in Fig. 5(a). By using a modified Sto?ber method, the SiO2@melamine-resorcinol-formaldehyde polymer spheres (SiO2@MRFPSs) were prepared firstly. Subsequently, the SiO2@N-doped porous carbon spheres were obtained by the pyrolysis of SiO2@MRFPSs at 700 °C under Ar. After HF etching to remove the silica core, the Co-N5/HNPCSs catalyst was obtained (Fig. 5(b) ). The monodispersed Co sites with 5-coordination were determined by the aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM, EXAFS and XPS analyses. The electrochemical measurements (Fig. 5(c)) revealed that the Co-N5/HNPCSs catalyst exhibited an remarkable catalytic activity for CO2RR, with the CO Faradaic efficiency up to 99.2% at –0.73 V, which was 15.5 times higher than that of cobalt phthalocyanine (CoPc). More importantly, the CO Faradaic efficiency (>90%) could be maintained over a wide potential range from –0.57 to –0.88 V (Fig. 5(d)). To unveil the role of the coordination structure of the Co sites on the reaction, the Co-N4/HNPCSs and Co-N3/HNPCSs catalysts were prepared by pyrolyzing Co-N5/HNPCSs at 400 and 600 °C, respectively. As the pyrolysis temperature was increased further, the Co NP catalyst was obtained. Similar to Co-N5/HNPCSs, the Co-N4/HNPCSs and Co-N3/HNPCSs could also catalyze the CO2 reduction, however, their high CO2 reduction ability could only be achieved at a certain potential. Nevertheless, the formation of Co NPs led to a significant decline in the CO2 reduction. As a result, the CO Faradaic efficiency of Co-N5/HNPCSs after treatment above 800 °C was lower than 50% at all potentials, thus, indicating that the isolated Co sites were responsible for the high catalytic activity. The DFT calculations were employed to explore the intrinsic properties of Co-N5/HNPCSs. The results reveal that the moderate impact of the CO binding on the Co center as well as the strong COOH interaction make it an ideal material for the CO2 reduction reaction (Fig. 5(e)). During chemisorption of CO or COOH, the adsorption energy (E ads) is approximately linear with respect to the d-band center (E dbc). This study not only led to the design of a powerful CO2 reduction electrocatalyst, but also provided a methodology for revealing the intrinsic catalytic active sites. Although the single-atom catalysts have been widely used in electrocatalysis due to their high atom utilization and excellent catalytic performance, however, the isolated active center can only catalyze the elementary reactions involving a single molecule due to the structural simplicity, whereas the activation step in a majority of the catalytic reactions usually involves multiple molecules. To improve the efficiency of catalytic conversion of CO2 to CO, a catalyst featuring two adjacent Cu atoms has been constructed, denoted as an ‘atom-pair catalyst’ (APC). In this catalyst, two adjacent Cu atoms work together to complete the key bimolecular activation step for CO2 reduction [ 83 ]. Specially, the Pd10Te3 alloy nanowires were synthesized first, followed by loading a controllable amount of Cu, ranging between 0 and 0.20 wt%. As shown in Figs. 6(a) and (b) , the alloy nanowires with a Cu loading of 0.10% exhibited the highest CO current for all potentials. At –0.78 V, the CO current density was determined to be 8.6 mA cm−2, which was 57 times higher than the undoped alloy nanowires (0.15 mA cm−2), thus, indicating a remarkably improved CO2 reduction activity. The extremely low Cu loading ensures the sparse distribution of the Cu atoms, which provides a basis to study the synergistic effect of the neighboring Cu atoms. Based on the X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), HRTEM, EDX line scanning analyses, and the DFT calculations, it was revealed that the synergistic effect between the Cu0-Cu x+ pair was responsible for the activation of the CO2 and H2O molecules. The calculation results further revealed that the metallic Cu0 acted as an active center for the CO2 binding and electron transfer, while the adjacent Cu x+ acted as a Lewis acid site, which could bind to H2O (Figs. 6(c) and (d)). The H atoms of the bound H2O molecules on the metallic Cu0 sites were sufficiently acidic to form hydrogen bonds with the O atoms in CO2, which enhanced the energetics of both hydride formation and CO binding, thus suppressing the competitive side reactions such as the reduction of protons to H2 and the subsequent reduction of CO. The theoretical results were consistent with the observed catalytic behavior on the Pd10Te3 alloy nanowires with the most abundant Cu0-Cu x+ pair, which corroborated the notion that the Cu0-Cu x+ pair was the real active center and served as the basis for the design of the CO2 reduction catalysts with high-performance. Overall, the Cu0-Cu x+ pair in the Pd10Te3 alloy nanowires presents a model system which endows the atomically dispersed catalysts with the ability for more complex reactions by constructing the functional interfaces at the atomic level. Recently, double-atom catalysts have emerged as a novel frontier in heterogeneous catalysis. For example, many carbon-based homonuclear and heteronuclear dimer catalysts such as Pt2 [ 84 ], Ni2 [ 85 ], Fe1-Co1 [ 86 ] and Pt1-Ru1 [ 87 ], have been studied and proven to be effective in both the electrochemical reactions (ORR, OER, HER and CO2RR) and the thermocatalytic reactions (CO oxidation, epoxidation of trans-stilbene, and the reverse water-gas shift reaction). The synergy of the double-atom catalyst enables it with the capability of breaking the linear scaling relation, which sheds light on the design of novel catalysts. Nevertheless, the application of double-atom catalysts is still limited owing to the challenge in the catalysts preparation and the computational design and prediction. 3 Photocatalysis Sunlight is the most abundant source of renewable energy, providing sufficient energy to meet the needs of humanity. However, it is intermittent and scattered, thus, it is vital to develop the pathways to harvest and store it for use, especially when the sun is not shining. The devices that use sunlight as a driving force to convert the raw materials into fine chemicals represent a promising solution. As compared with the conventional thermochemical approach, photochemistry can readily produce the reactive radicals, which promote challenging reactions proceed under mild conditions [ 88 ]. The key to improve the efficiency of the photocatalysts is to promote the photoinduced electron-hole separation and restrain the recombination. Theoretically, the different crystal facets differ in the energy band structures, thus, the electrons and holes formed on each facet would show different reduction and oxidation abilities [ 89 ]. Although many efforts have been devoted to reveal the facet effect, such effect has not been explored in detail. During photocatalysis, the dynamics of the minority carriers is very important, as the lifetime of the photogenerated carriers is mainly determined by the minority carriers. Recently, the WO3 nanosheets with {001} facets and one-dimensional nanowires with {110} facets (Figs. 7(a) and (b) ) have been successfully prepared. In contrast with the traditional qualitative analyses, the carrier dynamics on the different facets was quantitatively studied based on the DFT calculations and principles of semiconductor physics [ 90 ]. From the Hall effect measurements (Figs. 7(c)–(f)), it was noted that the WO3 nanowires with {110} facets possessed a higher electron density (7.638 × 1011 cm−3) than the WO3 nanosheets with {001} facets (2.145 × 1011 cm−3). On the other hand, the nanowires demonstrated a lower electron mobility (21.99 cm2 V−1 s−1) than the nanosheets (40.28 cm2 V−1 s−1). Besides the mobility, the diffusion length of the minority carriers is also critical to the photocatalytic performance, as a large hole diffusion length can restrain the recombination of the charge carriers and generate the durable holes. To determine the lifetime of the minority carriers, the fluorescence spectroscopy was employed. On exciting the WO3 nanowires and nanosheets at a wavelength of 360 nm, their fluorescence emission peaks were observed at around 456 nm (Fig. 7(g)). The high fluorescence intensity of the WO3 nanosheets suggested the faster recombination of excitons as compared to the WO3 nanowires (Fig. 7(h)). The results of transient fluorescence spectrum further confirmed that the hole lifetime on the WO3 nanosheets (350 ps) was shorter than the WO3 nanowires (440 ps). Thus, as compared to {001}, the hole diffusion length on {110} was much larger, thereby endowing the {110} facet with a superior photocatalytic activity. As a result, the WO3 nanowires with {110} facets exhibited a high benzyl alcohol (BA) conversion than the nanosheets with {001} facets, and the conversion rate of BA on the WO3 nanowires was 2.46 times higher than that on the nanosheets. Overall, the study revealed the facet effect on the photocatalytic reactions from a novel perspective, along with linking the physical theory to the photocatalytic behavior of the catalysts. In addition to the facet effect, the construction of the hetero-nanostructured materials has also been well established to facilitate the interfacial charge transfer and separation by the hybridization of the photocatalyst with the semiconductors or metals, thus, resulting in a built-in electric field [ 91,92 ]. However, such strategy requires the construction of heterogeneous interfaces. Owing to the limited contact interface area, the further improvement of photocatalytic performance is rather hindered. Recently, we have developed a novel approach to improve the electron-hole separation within the photocatalyst by coupling the Bi2WO6–x and BiOCl nanosheets (denoted as p-BWO nanosheets, Figs. 8(a) and (b) ) [ 93 ]. The as-prepared p-BWO nanosheets displayed an excellent photochromic behavior, owing to the partial reduction of the W(vi) species by the photogenerated electrons, as confirmed from the XPS analysis. On spraying the p-BWO powder with the reducing organic matter (such as ethanol and toluene), the photochromic response induced by the visible light was more conspicuous, and the resulting blue color could be swiftly bleached in the dark (Fig. 8(c)). The observed phenomena indicated that the photogenerated holes possessed a high activity and could be easily consumed by the organic molecules, whereas the dissolved O2 molecules could reverse the reduction of the W(vi) species. As a result, in the O2 atmosphere, the photogenerated electrons could be consumed via the cycle: W(vi) → W(v) → W(vi). It inhibited the electron-hole recombination and allowed the continuous participation of the holes in the photocatalytic oxidation. The significantly reduced photoluminescence response (Fig. 8(d)) indicated that the photoinduced carriers recombination in p-BWO was largely suppressed. Therefore, the photochromic reaction of p-BWO represented a macroscopic manifestation of the rapid carrier separation as well as an effective inhibition of the photogenerated electron-hole pair recombination. For the toluene oxidation reaction, which is a challenging task with high industrial value, the p-BWO could readily activate the C–H bonds of toluene into benzaldehyde or benzoic acid by tuning the reaction process. The observed conversion rate (2162 μmol g−1 h−1) was calculated to be 166 times higher than that of the Bi2WO6, far exceeding the earlier reported photocatalysts (Fig. 8(e)). Based on a series of 18O2 labeling experiments as well as XAS and XPS analyses, a catalytic mechanism of the p-BWO catalyst (Fig. 8(f)) has been proposed. For the Bi2WO6 semiconductors, the bottom of the conduction band and top of the valence band are composed of the W 5d and Bi 6s + O 2p orbitals, respectively. On exposing p-BWO to light, the electron-hole pairs are formed. Subsequently, the holes can activate toluene to form the R• radicals, and the electrons reduce W(vi) into W(v), thus, resulting in the photochromic phenomenon. The W(v) species can be oxidized by O2 to form the •O2– radicals and W(vi), thus, completing the photochromism cycle. Moreover, the abundant crystalline-amorphous boundaries in the p-BWO nanosheets not only shorten the migration length, but also provide an abundance of the W(vi)O6–x units to capture the photogenerated electrons. The capture of the photogenerated electrons results in photochromism and enhances the separation of the photogenerated carriers. Thus, the efficiency of the photoinduced holes is dramatically improved, which facilitated the C–H activation in toluene, thereby endowing the p-BWO with a remarkable activity. 3 Thermocatalysis 3.1 Silane oxidation Silanols are important building blocks in the polymer industry [ 94 ]. Traditionally, silanols are prepared from silanes, in which the strong oxidants with the stoichiometric amounts are often involved, leading to the generation of siloxanes and other environmentally unfavorable by-products [ 95,96 ]. The selective oxidation of silanes by using H2O as an oxidant has attracted a significant attention due to its cost effectiveness, environmental friendliness and safety. By far, mainly due to the unique selectivity, the heterogeneous Au catalysts have received a particular attention, with both the nanoporous Au and Au NPs exhibiting excellent catalytic activity and selectivity [ 97,98 ]. The heterogeneous Au nanocatalysts suffer from a relatively low atomic efficiency. A promising alternative is to develop the single-atom Au catalysts with porous structures. However, due to the weak binding nature of Au, minimizing the agglomeration of gold to achieve a high catalytic performance is still a major challenge. In a recent study, we have successfully constructed a single-atom Au catalyst by using the polymeric mesoporous C3N4 (mpg-C3N4) as a support (Figs. 9(a) and (b) ) [ 99 ]. Au1/mpg-C3N4 has been proved to be an efficient catalyst for organosilanes oxidation. With different substrates, silanols were the sole product, and no siloxanes were observed. Au1/mpg-C3N4 was extremely active for the oxidation of dimethylphenylsilane (Fig. 9(c)), with the calculated TOF up to 50200 h−1, far exceeding the reported Au catalysts. Moreover, the Au1/mpg-C3N4 was highly durable during the reaction, with no obvious Au leaching. The aberration-corrected STEM, XPS and EXAFS analyses concluded that the isolated Au atoms were anchored in the tri-s-triazine heterocyclic rings with an oxidation state of mainly +1. To gain insights about the key catalytic species, the performance of the homogeneous AuI salt, Au(PPh3)Cl and AuIII salt have been compared. The AuI species are observed to be the real active sites for the silane oxidation. During the reaction, AuI undergoes the oxidative insertion in the Si–H bond to form the Si-AuIII-H intermediate. Thereafter, the intermediate reacts with H2O to generate silanol and H2 (Fig. 9(d)). Overall, for the first time, the capability of the heterogeneous single-site AuI for the Si–H activation has been depicted. 3.2 Benzene oxidation Phenol is a raw material and organic chemical intermediate for many industrial products such as phenolic resin, carbonate, and cyclohexanol [ 100 ]. Currently, the industrialized process using benzene as a raw material has significant disadvantages, including complex synthesis routes, high raw material consumption and environmental pollution [ 101 ]. Thus, the direct oxidation of benzene by using H2O2 as the oxide agent is of high industrial significance. As a result, the development of the advanced catalysts for benzene direct oxidation has been a focus of research. Over the past few decades, many non-noble metal catalysts for benzene oxidation have been reported; however, these typically suffer from the low catalytic performances [ 102 ]. In order to design the efficient benzene oxidation catalysts, the knowledge of the exact structure of the active sites is of paramount importance. SACs offer an ideal platform to identify the active center and the reaction mechanism during benzene oxidation. For this purpose, a strategy based on polymerization-regulated pyrolysis has been developed to prepare a range of atomically dispersed Fe-N x C y catalysts to study the structure-sensitive reactions [ 103 ]. The aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM and EXAFS analyses revealed that the iron-polyphthalocyanine polymer could be readily converted to the Fe-N x C y catalysts with different Fe-N coordination numbers by regulating the pyrolysis temperature (500 °C for Fe-N4, 600 °C for Fe-N3C1 and 700 °C for Fe-N2C2, Figs. 10(a)–(h) ). The experimental measurements (Figs. 10(i) and (j)) demonstrated that the isolated Fe sites with four coordinated N atoms exhibited the highest benzene oxidation activity, which surpassed the performance of the previously reported benzene oxidation catalysts. Interestingly, the benzene oxidation activity of the isolated Fe site decreased when the coordinated N atoms were substituted by C atoms, thus, suggesting a remarkable structure-sensitivity. The 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) and DFT calculations further revealed the intrinsic coordination effect on the reaction. Specifically, the coordination manner influenced not only the geometric/electronic structure the Fe centers, but also the activation of the substrate and selection of the catalytic reaction pathway. The increase in the N coordination number facilitated the activation and formation of the O=Fe=O intermediate species, thus, improving the benzene oxidation activity. The study not only presented the development of an efficient benzene oxidation catalyst, but also provided insights into the structure-sensitive reactions at the atomic level. 3.3 N-formylation of amines with CO2 Formamides are widely used as raw materials during industrial syntheses [ 104 ]. Among the various approaches employed for the production of formamides, the N-formylation of amines with formic acid/formate is the most commonly used method [ 105 ]. An alternative green method for the N-formylation of amines involves the use of the low-cost, abundant CO2 as a formylating reagent [ 106 ]. The development of this technology has received a considerable attention from both industry and academia. As the high atom utilization and unsaturated coordination of SACs can significantly improve the efficiency of the processes, thus, it is of high environmental and social relevance to explore SACs for the N-formylation reactions. However, owing to the high surface energy, the isolated metal atoms in SACs have a strong tendency to aggregate into nanoparticles during the reaction. In a recent study, we have presented an atomically dispersed Pt catalyst with an outstanding stability by employing the ultrathin two-dimensional (2D) Ti3–x C2T y MXene as a support [ 107 ]. The Ti3–x C2T y MXene comprises three Ti sublayers with C located at the octahedral interstitial sites, and the neighboring two layers are connected by a Al layer. On using HF to etch the Al atoms to exfoliate the ultrathin multilayered MXenes, a few adjacent Ti atoms are also etched off, thus, resulting in the formation of the Ti vacancies. These vacancy defects are reducible, which make the 2D Ti3–x C2T y MXene a promising candidate for synthesizing single-atom Pt catalysts via a in-situ reduction process (Fig. 11(a) ). The aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM and EXAFS measurements revealed that the isolated Pt atoms were anchored in the Ti vacancies (Figs. 11(b) and (d)). The Pt1/Ti3–x C2T y catalyst exhibited an efficient activity for the N-formylation of aniline and CO2 under mild conditions, with the turnover number (TON) far exceeding that of Ti3–x C2T y supported Pt NPs and commercial Pt catalyst (Fig. 11(c)). The results of DFT calculations showed that, compared to the Pt NPs on the Ti3–x C2T y support, the isolated Pt atoms were partial positive (Fig. 11(e)), which significantly decreased the adsorption and activation energies of CO2, silane and aniline, thus improving the catalytic performances. Moreover, the method is also applicable to the other noble metals (Rh, Ru, Pd and Ir), thus, signifying a general and robust pathway for the preparation of SACs. 4 Summery and perspectives Nano-catalysis plays a critical role in the chemical industry. The modern catalysis science is undergoing a major change and even a revolution to meet the needs for the sustainable development of the society. In order to achieve the efficient and stable heterogeneous catalysts, it is of paramount importance to gain insights into the fundamental properties, such as the coordination structures of the active centers, element-doping-induced electronic effects and substrate-adsorbate interactions. In this account, we have summarized our recent studies combining the synthetic chemistry, theoretical modeling and spectroscopy analysis dealing with the development of a range of nano-catalysts for applications in electrocatalysis, photocatalysis and thermocatalysis. It is believed that the strategies developed for the nano-catalysts synthesis and research methodologies established for identifying the active sites would significantly improve the development of the modern catalysis. However, despite the significant advancements so far, many major challenges are still needed to be addressed. One important and daunting task is to identify the true active site and synthesize the desired active centers with identical nanostructures. Theoretically, this task can be solved via the efforts by combining advanced synthetic methodologies, characterization techniques, and DFT calculations. However, all the above tools currently present several shortcomings, which make researchers lose confidence in achieving the goal of precise synthesis of desired catalytic active structures. For example, although it is now feasible to prepare various forms of SACs, yet the selective synthesis with a precise control of the surface structure and amount/distribution of the dopants (such as P and N) remains difficult. Secondly, the development of characterization techniques to analyze certain active sites for heterogeneous nanocatalysts remains a major challenge, owing to the diversity of active sites in heterogeneous nanocatalysts (which involve metal surface sites, active support sites, interfacial sites and reaction-induced dynamic active sites, etc.). Thirdly, the current computational chemistry can hardly approximate the complexity of the real catalytic systems. As the design of nanocatalysts based on detailed synthetic understanding must still be considered a long-term objective, it is essential to develop novel strategies that can circumvent these limitations for achieving visible breakthroughs in catalysis science. In recent years, some strategies have been proposed and are being evaluated in our group devoted to achieving these breakthroughs. For example, seeking suitable agents to poison the active sites selectively, which is beneficial to reduce the diversity of active sites for higher product selectivity, and also provides the prerequisites for analyzing certain active centers with current characterization techniques. Overall, the challenges and barriers are significant, and so are the opportunities. Chen Chen received his BS degree from the Department of Chemistry, Beijing Institute of Technology in 2006, and his PhD degree from the Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University in 2011. After the postdoctoral work at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, he joined the Department of Chemistry at Tsinghua University as an Associate Professor in 2015, and was promoted to Professor with tenure in 2021. His research interests are focused on nanomaterials for catalysis and sustainable energy. His name is in the lists of Highly Cited Researchers 2021 from Clarivate. He joined the Editorial Board of Chinese Journal of Catalysis in 2020.

coredata.dc:description: Nano-catalysis plays a vital role in the chemical transformations and significantly impacts the booming modern chemical industry. The rapid technological enhancements have resulted in serious energy and environmental issues, which are currently spurring the exploration of the novel nano-catalysts in diverse fields. In order to develop the efficient nano-catalysts, it is essential to understand their fundamental physicochemical properties, including the coordination structures of the active centers and substrate-adsorbate interactions. Subsequently, the nano-catalyst design with precise manipulation at the atomic level can be attained. In this account, we have summarized our extensive investigation of the factors impacting nano-catalysis, along with the synthetic strategies developed to prepare the nano-catalysts for applications in electrocatalysis, photocatalysis and thermocatalysis. Finally, a brief conclusion and future research directions on nano-catalysis have also been presented.

coredata.dc:title: Rational design and precise manipulation of nano-catalysts
